Èöè‰æøÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∫õÁΩÆÈ°∂ÂêßÔºåÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏ä‰πüÊ≤°‰ªÄ‰πàÂ•ΩËØ¥ÁöÑÔºåÊàë‰ºöÂú®Ëøô‰∏™ÂçöÂÆ¢ÈáåËÆ∞ÂΩï‰∏Ä‰∫õËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÁîüÊ¥ªÊó•Â∏∏ÔºåÊâÄÊÄùÊâÄÊÉ≥Ôºå‰ª•ÂèäÂ≠¶‰π†Á¨îËÆ∞„ÄÇ

ËØ¥ÂÆûËØùÂæà‰πÖ‰ª•ÂâçÂ∞±ÊúâÂàõÂª∫Â±û‰∫éËá™Â∑±ÁΩëÁ´ôÁöÑÊÉ≥Ê≥ïÔºåÂè™ÊòØÂõ∞‰∫éÊäÄÊúØÂíåË¥¢ÂäõÔºåËøüËøüÈÉΩÊ≤°Âä®ÊâãÔºåÁé∞Âú®Áü•ÈÅì‰∫ÜÂèØ‰ª•Ëøô‰πàÂÅö‰∫éÊòØÂ∞±Êúâ‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™blog„ÄÇ

ÂÅöÁöÑ‰∏çÂ•ΩÔºåÂ§ßÂ§öËøòÊòØÊ®°ÊùøÈáåÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπÔºå‰∏çÂ§™Êï¢Êîπ‰∫õËä±ÈáåËÉ°Âì®ÁöÑÔºåÂ§ßÊäµÊàëÁé∞Âú®ÊäÄÊúØÂäõ‰πüÂ∞±ËøôÊ†∑ÔºåÊÅ≥ËØ∑ÂêÑ‰ΩçÂ§ß‰Ω¨ËΩªÂñ∑„ÄÇ

ÊàëËá™Â∑±‰ºö‰∏çÂÆöÊó∂Âú∞Êù•ÁúãÁúãÔºåÂä†‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰∏úË•øÊàñËÄÖÊîπ‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰∏úË•øÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÁúãÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâÁ©∫‰ΩôÊó∂Èó¥‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

‰πüÊ¨¢ËøéÂêÑ‰ΩçË∑ØËøáÁöÑÁúãÂÆ¢Âà∞ËØÑËÆ∫Âå∫ÁïôË®ÄÂì¶„ÄÇüòâ

Èöè‰æøÂÖàÊîπ‰∏ÄÊîπHello World. Á™ÅÁÑ∂ËÆ∞Ëµ∑Êù•ÂΩìÂπ¥Âú®Ê¥õË∞∑ËøõÂéªÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÈ¢òHello World!Êàë‰∫§‰∫Ü‰∏âÈÅçÊâçËøáÊù•ÁùÄÔºå‰∏çËøáËøôÂõûÂ∞±‰∏çÁî®Áúã‰∫∫ÂÆ∂Êú∫Âô®Áªô‰∏çÁªôËøá‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ÊÉ≥‰∫ÜÂçäÂ§©Â∫ï‰∏ãËøô‰∏ÄÁ•®Ë¶Å‰∏çË¶ÅÂà†ÔºåÊâìÁÆóÂÖàÁïôÁùÄ‰∫ÜÔºåÊØïÁ´ü‰∏çËàçÂæóÊâî‰∏úË•øÂà†‰∏úË•ø‰πüÊòØËÄÅ‰π†ÊÉØ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

entry.title: Elements of data processing
entry.content:
Elements of data processing

Á∫ØÁ∫ØÊúüÊú´‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂ§ç‰π†Ë°•ÁöÑÔºåÂ•Ω‰∫ãÊòØËÄÉËØïÈíàÂØπÊÄßÂº∫ÔºåÁº∫ÁÇπÊòØÂ§ßÊ¶ÇÊå∫ÈöæÁúãÊáÇÁöÑ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂõæÁâáÊúâÁÇπÈöæÊêûÔºåÊàëÂæóÂÖàÊÉ≥‰∏™ÂäûÊ≥ïËÉΩËÆ©‰º†ÂõæÁâáÊñπ‰æø‰∏ÄÁÇπÂÜç‰øÆÔºåÂ§ßÊ¶ÇÁü•ÈÅìÊÄé‰πà‰øÆ‰∫ÜÔºüÊâæ‰∏™Êó∂Èó¥ÂºÑ‰∏ÄÂºÑÔºå‰∏çËøátyporaÊòæÁ§∫‰∏çÂá∫Êù•ÊàëÊúâÁÇπÊÄ•‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

TheoryÔºö

data types:

Summarising:

  1. mathematical summary
  2. visual summary

descriptive statistics:

  • Count (frequency)
  • min, max, range
  • quartiles, percentiles
  • mean, median, mode
  • Variance, standard deviation

visualisation:

efficient and effective

  1. line plots

  2. boxplots

    Q1: 25% point below median

    Q3: 25% point above median

    IQR (Interquartile range) = Q3-Q1

    Upper/Lower limits:

    Q3+1.5*IQR or Q1-1.5*IQR

    Whiskers (inner fence)

    if the Highest/lowest data points are within 1.5* IQR range, it's called upper/lower inner fence

    outliers:

    suspected outlier (use circle to indicate)

    • > 1.5*IQR below Q1 or above Q3

    outliers (use black dot)

    • > 3*IQR below Q1 or above Q3

  3. histograms

    bars touches each other

    symmetric, left/right skewed, unimodal, bimodal, multimodal...

    problem: choose an appropriate bin size for histogram

    Áî®‰∫énumerical data

  4. bar charts

    Áî®‰∫écategorical data: not continuousÊâÄ‰ª•bar‰∏çË¥¥Âú®‰∏ÄËµ∑

    histogram vs bar chartsÔºö

  5. scatter plots

    x,yÂùêÊ†áÈÉΩÊòØnumerical

    ÂèòÁßçÔºàÁî®‰∫éÊòæÁ§∫Á¨¨‰∏âÈ°πÁâπÂæÅÔºâÔºöbubble plotÔºàÁÇπÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÔºâ/ enhanced scatter plotÔºàÈ¢úËâ≤Ôºâ

    ÂΩìÊï∞ÊçÆÂ§öÊó∂Ôºå‰ºöÂá∫Áé∞overplottingÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÁÇπÂÖ®ÈáçÂè†Âú®‰∏ÄËµ∑ÔºåÁúã‰∏çÊ∏ÖÔºåÂèØ‰ª•reduce dot size, sampling(Áî®Â∞èÁöÑÊ†∑Êú¨Èáè), jitter or use other plots

  6. heatmap

    normalise the data first

  7. parallel coordinate plots

    high-dimensional data

    Ê≥®ÊÑèscalingÔºåordering‰πüÂæàÈáçË¶ÅÔºåÂ•ΩÁöÑorderingÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©Êï∞ÊçÆÊõ¥Âä†Ê∏ÖÊô∞

Click to expand!

Heading

  1. A numbered
  2. list
    • With some
    • Sub bullets

Coding

matplotlib

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot(x,y)ÁîªÂõæÔºåÊúâÁÇπÂÉèmatlabÔºà‰∏çÊòØÊúâÁÇπÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ†∑Ôºâplot(y)Ôºå‰ºöËá™Âä®ÁîüÊàêxÂùêÊ†á

panda

import panda as pd

series:

ÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÂàóË°®/Â≠óÂÖ∏ÂàõÂª∫<something> = pd.Series(<list/dict>)

Examples of series attributes:

  • series.index attribute (returns the index field like dict.keys()) ÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÂàóË°®Êù•ËµãÂÄº
  • series.values attribute (returns the values like dict.values())

Examples of series methods: - series.mean() method (computes the average) - series.sum() method (computes the grand total sum)

pd.concat([LIST OF SERIES], axis='rows')ÂêàÂπ∂‰∏§‰∏™series

series.loc[]Áî®‰∫éslicingÔºåÊã¨Âè∑ÈáåÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØindexÔºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØÈíàÂØπÊï∞ÂÄºÁöÑË°®ËææÂºè

.iloc[]ÈíàÂØπindicesÊù•slicing

pd.read_csvÂèØ‰ª•ËØªÂèñcsv file

<csv_file>.head(10)ÁîªË°®Ê†ºÔºåËøôhead(10)Êàë‰πü‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìÊòØÂï•ÊÑèÊÄùÔºå‰ΩÜËæìÂá∫‰∫Ü‰∏™Ë°®Ê†º

Week2

pre-processing

measuring data quality

  • Accuracy: right or wrong
  • Completeness: Not recorded, unavailable (missing completely at random (unrelated to other variables)/ at random (relates to other variables)/ not at random (based on the variable itself))
  • Consistency: discrepancies in representation (naming representations, date formats, outliers, etc.)
  • Timeliness: Updated in a timely way
  • Believability: Can I trust the data
  • Interpretability: How easy can it be understand

deal with incomplete data: 1. sklearn 2. multivariate strategies

missing at random: relate to some other data

completely at random: not related to anything

not at random: relate to the data itself

precision=\(\frac{TP}{TP+FP}\)

recall=\(\frac{TP}{TP+FN}\)

Accuracy=\(\frac{TP+TN}{TP+TN+FP+FN}\)

pearson correlation:

\(r_{xy}=\frac {\sum _{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-{\bar {x}})(y_{i}-{\bar {y}})}{\sqrt {\sum _{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-{\bar {x}})^2}\sqrt {\sum _{i=1}^{n}(y_{i}-{\bar {y}})^2}}\)

\(\frac{\text{Cov}(x,y)}{\sigma_x\sigma_y}\), Cov(x,y)=E(x-xbar)(y-ybar) covariance

linear relationship ONLY and continuous prefered

np.arange(13)+0.5 == array([ 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5, 6.5, 7.5, 8.5, 9.5, 10.5, 11.5, 12.5])

Jaccard similarity

S√∏rensen-Dice similarity

Cosine similarity

Entropy

For example: - An unbiased coin flip (50% Heads, 50% Tails) will have an entropy of 1. - A biased coin flip (100% Heads, 0% Tails) will have an entropy of 0.

\(H(X) = -\sum P(X=x_i)\log_2(P(X=x_i))\)

Conditional Entropy

\(H(Y|X) = \sum_{x_i \in X} P(X=x_i) H(Y|X=x_i)\)

where \(H(Y|X=x)\) means calculating the entropy of the distribution \(P(Y|X=x)\):

\[H(Y|X=x) = -\sum_{y_j \in Y} P(Y=y_j|X=x)\log_2(P(Y=y_j|X=x)).\]

Mutual Information(shannon version)

\(\text{MI}(X, Y) = H(X) ‚Äì H(X | Y) = H(Y) - H(Y | X)\)

normalized Mutual Information: (between 0 and 1)

\(\text{NMI}(X, Y) = \frac{\text{MI}(X,Y)}{min(H(X),H(Y))}\)

if \(MI=0\): X and Y are independent

Chi-squared value

\(\chi^2=\sum\frac{(O_i-E_i)^2}{E_i}\)

subset accuracy & average accuracy

correlation

+/-, how strong, linear/non-linear

The Pearson correlation coefficient, also referred to as Pearson's r, is a statistic that measures linear correlation between two variables X and Y.

ratio data and interval data and nomial data: ‰æãÂ≠êÂàÜÂà´ÊòØÊàøÂ≠êÂ§ßÂ∞èÔºà0ÁÇπÁªùÂØπÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊØîÂ§ßÂ∞èÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊâæÂá∫ÂÄçÊï∞ÂÖ≥Á≥ªetcÔºâÔºåÊàøÂ≠êÊàøÈó¥Êï∞Ôºà0ÁÇπÊ®°Á≥äÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÊØîËæÉÂÄçÊï∞ÂÖ≥Á≥ªÂ§üÂëõÔºåÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™‰æãÂ≠êÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØÊ∏©Â∫¶ÔºàÊëÑÊ∞èÂ∫¶ÔºâÔºâÔºåÊàøÂ≠êÈó®ÁâåÂè∑ÔºàÂçïÁ∫ØÁöÑÁªô‰∏™ÂêçÂ≠óËÄåÂ∑≤Ôºâ

The coefficient of determination is the portion of the total variation in the dependent variable that is explained by variation in the independent variable.

causation: regression is not causal, correlation doesn't mean causation.

visualization techniques

line plots

boxplots

histograms

bar charts

scatter plots (scatter plot matrix)

heatmap

parallel coordinate plots

JSON and XML: semi-structured format

- json

-- part structured data -- values from article metadata;

-- part non-structured -- text throughout article

- xml

-- metadata requires structure allowed by xml format;

--

JSON vs CSV: JSON is more expressive than CSV as it allows nesting, objects and arrays cannot be represented in a single line in a CSV file

Regex

text processing:

remove punc

casefolding

tokenisation

remove stopword

lemmatisation, stemming

TF-IDF and BoW: (representation model) convert unstructured text to a feature representation

machine learning:

kfold: we split the data into n parts (folds), one fold istesting, the rest training, we round-robin the testing fold, eventually we average results.

supervised vs unsupervised: Supervised = we have labelled data, unsupervised = we do not have labels.

unsupervised: PCA visualisation, feature selections

clustering

k-anonymous: Â∑≤Áü•‰ø°ÊÅØÁªÑÂêàÔºåÊúÄÂ∞èÁöÑsetÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞è

I-diversity: ÊØèÁßç‰ø°ÊÅØÁªÑÂêàÔºåsensitiveÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÁßçÁ±ªÊï∞ÁõÆÁöÑÊúÄÂ∞èÂÄº

global sensitivity: Â∞±ÊòØÊØè‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìËÉΩÂç†ÁöÑÊúÄÂ§öÊï∞Èáè

recommender system:

1.Â°´Ë°•Á©∫Áº∫ÔºöÁî®xx-base‰∏≠xxÁöÑÂπ≥ÂùáÂÄºÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúxxÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂÄºÁº∫Â§±ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÂøΩÁï•

\(\text{sim}(i_i, i_j)=\frac{1}{1+d(i_i,i_j)}\)

ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂ∞±ÊòØÁÆóÂä†ÊùÉÂπ≥ÂùáÂÄº

Dictionary attack

Zook‚Äôs ‚Äô10 simple rules for responsible big data research

  1. Acknowledge that data are people and can do harm

    ‚Äì All data are people until proven otherwise

    • Social media
    • Heart rates from Youtube videos
    • Ocean measurements that change property risk profiles

  2. Recognize that privacy is more than a binary value

    ‚Äì Privacy is contextual and situational

    ‚Äì Single Instagram photo versus entire history of social media posts

    ‚Äì Privacy preferences differ across individuals and societies

  3. Guard against the reidentification of your data

    ‚Äì Metadata associated with photos

    ‚Äì Reverse image search ‚Äì connect dating and professional profiles

    ‚Äì Difficult to recognize the vulnerable points a-priori!

    • Battery usage on a phone ‚Äì can reveal a person‚Äôs location

  4. Practice ethical data sharing

    ‚Äì Seeking consent from participants to share data

  5. Consider the strengths and limitations of your data; big does not automatically mean better

    ‚Äì Document the provenance and evolution of your data. Do not overstate clarity; acknowledge messiness and multiple meanings.

    • is a Facebook post or an Instagram photo best interpreted as an approval/disapproval of a phenomenon, a simple observation, or an effort to improve status within a friend network?

  6. Debate the tough, ethical choices/issues

    ‚Äì importance of debating the issues within groups of peers

    • Examples mentioned earlier

      ‚Äì Facebook emotional contagion

      ‚Äì Exposing teen girl‚Äôs pregnancy

    • More recently, Google Duplex

      ‚Äì https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D5VN56jQMWM

  7. Develop a code of conduct for your organization, research community, or industry

    ‚Äì Are we abiding by the terms of service or users‚Äô expectations?

    ‚Äì Does the general public consider our research ‚Äúcreepy‚Äù?

  8. Design your data and systems for auditability

    ‚Äì Plan for and welcome audits of your big data practices.

    ‚Äì Systems of auditability clarify how different datasets (and the subsequent analysis) differ from each other, aiding understanding and creating better research

    • ‚ÄúFor example, many types of social media and other trace data are unstructured, and answers to even basic questions such as network links depend on the steps taken to collect and collate data.‚Äù

  9. Engage with the broader consequences of data and analysis practices

    ‚Äì Recognize that doing big data research has societal-wide effects

  10. Know when to break these rules

    ‚Äì Natural disaster

    ‚Äì Public health emergency

    ‚Äì Hostile enemy

    ‚Äì ‚Ä¶

Boolean‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ËøõË°åÁÆóÊúØËøêÁÆóÔºåÊ≠§Êó∂FalseË¢´Áúã‰Ωú0ÔºåTrueË¢´Áúã‰Ωú1

Ë°®ËææÂºèÔºö

Expression: some code which generates an object. This could be a literal or a previously-assigned identifier. It could be an operation, or a function/method call. It could be an index or slice of a sequence. A function call can be thought of as an expression which evaluates to its return value.

Simple Expression: An expression containing only an operator and its operand(s) as literals or variables.

Complex Expression: An expression with more parts than a simple expression. This could be expression with an operator where the operands are expressions themselves, such as the operands of / in (2 + 4) / (4 - 3)

Logical Expression: An expression which evaluates to a bool. Usually contains some combination of logical and relational operators.

Statement: Anything which is a valid line of Python code. This includes all expressions, but also lines with def, return, if, elif, else. It also includes assignment operations (=).

Lists, dictionaries and sets are mutable.

Everything else is immutable ‚Äî strings, tuples and numbers (including ints, floats and booleans).

NamespaceÔºàÂëΩÂêçÁ©∫Èó¥ÔºâÔºöusing namespace std;

local namespaceÔºàÂ±ÄÈÉ®ÂêçÁß∞ÔºâÂíåglobal namespaceÔºàÂÖ®Â±ÄÂêçÁß∞ÔºâÔºöÂáΩÊï∞ËøêË°åÊó∂‰ºöÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™local namespaceÔºåÂíåglobalÂÆåÂÖ®Âå∫ÂàÜÂºÄ

By default, variables in functions are dereferenced relative to the local namespace

Dereferencing is a process where a variable name is queried to find the object which is assigned to it.

We often use the word scope to the area of code where a particular namespace is used.

when a variable is encountered in a function, Python first attempts to dereference it relative to the local namespace (of the current function call), and failing this, it attempts to dereference it relative to the global namespace, bypassing the local namespace of any other functions.

Â∑Æ‰∏çÂ§öÊòØÂú®ÂáΩÊï∞‰∏≠‰ºöÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™local namespaceÔºåÈáåÈù¢ÂØπ‰∫éÂèòÈáèÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÂπ∂‰∏ç‰ºöÂΩ±ÂìçÂ§ñÈù¢ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂÄºÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂáΩÊï∞‰∏≠ËÆøÈóÆ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®‰∫élocal‰ΩÜÂ≠òÂú®‰∫églobal‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèòÈáè‰ΩÜ‰∏çËÉΩÁõ¥Êé•ÂØπglobal‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèòÈáèËøõË°åÊõ¥ÊîπÔºå‰ºö‰∫ßÁîüUnboundLocalErrorÔºåÂΩìÁÑ∂ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñ∞ÁöÑÁã¨Á´ã‰∫églobalÁöÑÊòØÂêàÊ≥ïÁöÑ

ÂØπ‰∫éËøîÂõûÂÄºÔºåÊ†πÊçÆÂõæÁâácolour-modeËøîÂõû‰∏çÂêå

  • For a black and white image (mode "1"), it will be 0 for black, or 1 for white.
  • For a greyscale image (mode "L"), it will be a number between 0 and 255 (inclusive): 0 for black, 255 for white.
  • For an RGB image (mode "RGB"), it will be a 3-tuple of values. This tuple will contain three values, all between 0 and 255 (inclusive). The first value will be the amount of red in the pixel, the second the amount of green, and then third the amount of blue. In each channel, 0 represents absence of that colour and 255 represents the full amount of that colour.

worksheet 18

Data science

involve 4 stepsÔºö

  1. data wrangling: cleaning up the raw data to remove anomalies, integrate data from multiple sources into a single format, and generally make it easier to use; this is often one of the most time-consuming and tedious parts of data science, but is an essential first step, as "garbage in, garbage out"
  2. data visualisation: generating visual representations of the data in different ways, both as a pre-step to "get to know" the data (based on different breakdowns of the data) and as a post-step to better understand what has been gleaned about the data
  3. data analysis: statistical analysis of the data to "model" some aspect of it, in terms of unearthing patterns in the data, or predicting things about new events/behaviours.
  4. empirical evaluation: measurement of the "correctness" of a given data analysis model to the data, in terms of how well it is expected to predict future events/behaviours, or how well it "fits" the data.

Exception Description
IndexError Raised when a sequence index is out of range, e.g. [][0].
ZeroDivisionError Raised when the second argument of a division or modulo operation is zero, e.g. 1/0.
TypeError Raised when an operation or function is applied to an inappropriate type, e.g. 'e'+3
NameError Raised when you try to reference a variable which hasn't been assigned, e.g. num.
KeyError Raised when a key does not exist in the dictionary, e.g. {}['a'].

unicode & text encoding

The "validation" involves determining whether a sentence is grammatically correct. For that, we provide a toy grammar as follows:

Or, we can better illustrate it as follows:

S ‚Äì> NP VP VP ‚Äì> IV | TV PN NP ‚Äì> N | D N IV ‚Äì> runs | sits PN‚Äì> john | mary N ‚Äì> squirrel | cat | mouse | dog | tree TV ‚Äì> chases | catches | tells | sees | eats D‚Äì> the | a

This grammar states that a sentence (S) is composed of a noun phrase (NP) followed by a verb phase (VP). VP may be either an intransitive verb (IV) or a tranvisitve verb (TV) followed by a proper noun (PN). NP is either a noun (N) or a determiner followed by a noun (D N). For each class (so called "non-terminal") such as PN,N, TV, IV, D we provide a list of words (terminals) writter in lowercase (cat, tells, etc.). Using this grammar, we can generate sentences such as the mouse eats john or the tree runs as well as check whether a sentence is acceptable given the grammar (i.e. can be produced using the grammar rules). For instace, a sentence a cat sees mary is valid since is can be produced/parsed using the following grammar rules [[ a.D cat.N].NP [sees.TV mary.PN].VP].S (i.e. we are able to reach S) whereas a sentence a cat sits mary is not (there is no rule that has IV PN in the righthand side).

We would like to write a function that checks whether a sentence is accepted by the grammar or not. For that, we will first generate all possible sentences that can be produced using these rules (produce_sents) and then check if the sentence we are interested in appears there (validate).

We will assume that in the righthand part we always have either one or two non-terminals (classes written in uppercase) or a single terminal (words, not phrases, written in lowercase). We also assume that the hierarchy structure (the depth) is the same as in the provided toy example.

Example calls to the function are:

Complete the code by providing a single statement to insert into each of the numbered boxes. Note that your code should run at the indentation level indicated for each box.
